awd_titl_txt: Understanding and Reducing Biases in Jury Decision Making
awd_abstract_narration:
This research addresses questions about racial and ethnic prejudice in criminal trials. Reviews of convictions and sentencing in actual cases, and findings from trial simulation experiments, provide evidence of discrimination against minorities.  National polls and media stories reveal that prejudice remains prevalent in America.  But research has provided little insight into how prejudice operates in the courtroom and has not identified critical factors that increase or decrease discrimination.  Through a series of experiments involving trial simulations, the project seeks better theoretical understanding of how and when a defendant's race/ethnicity influences jury decisions.  It also aims to identify interventions that lessen courtroom bias, thereby providing policy and practice suggestions to the legal community.  These are important undertakings in a diverse society that seeks equal justice for all.  

Eight trial simulation experiments will be conducted in which Black, Hispanic, and White jury-eligible citizens serve as mock-jurors.  They will provide verdict preferences and other impressions after reviewing a trial in which the defendant is a member of either their racial/ethnic group (an "ingroup" defendant) or one of the other groups (an "outgroup" defendant).  In some experiments, mock-jurors will also deliberate.  Social-psychological theory guides the research and offers a framework for integrating diverse findings from sociology, criminal justice, criminology, and psychology.  Based on social-psychological theory, a sense of threat -- to social identity, cultural worldview, or security -- should increase discrimination in the form of greater perceived guilt and convictions of outgroup defendants.  Prejudice is understood to exist at an unconscious or implicit level, even among many who consciously reject prejudice.  To assess the impact of these factors, some experiments examine whether discrimination increases when participant-jurors experience these threats through information encountered prior to the trial.  Additional experiments focus on ways to reduce discrimination, including judges' instructions to guard against prejudice and the opportunity to deliberate. Results will inform decision making in the criminal justice system.

por.por_cntn:
Ten trial simulation experiments were conducted to study whether and when jurors are likely to discriminate against outgroup defendants – those who do not share their race or ethnicity -- and the extent to which remedies available in the conduct of trials may reduce such bias.  More than 1100 community residents and 800 college students either read a computer presentation of an abridged transcript of a criminal trial or watched a video enactment of the trial.  Afterward, these participant-jurors indicated their verdict preference and rated the strength of evidence against and likely guilt of the defendant.  In some experiments, they also deliberated about the trial in 3-to-8-person groups.  In all experiments, Black, Hispanic, and non-Hispanic White participant-jurors read or watched a trial in which the defendant was either Black, Hispanic, or White.  Thus, the participant-juror and defendant were either the same (ingroup defendant) or different (outgroup defendant) in race/ethnicity.  A higher frequency of guilty verdict preferences when the defendant is an outgroup (vs. ingroup) member was taken as evidence of defendant outgroup discrimination.

         Discrimination against outgroup defendants was observed to various degrees in 8 of 10 experiments.  Moreover, outgroup discrimination was evident for Black, Hispanic, and, to a lesser extent, White participants – each group typically was less likely judge “one of its own” guilty.

        Social science research indicates that people are more likely to behave in prejudiced ways when they feel threatened.  This proved true in a trial context as well.  Several forms of threat were found to increase defendant outgroup discrimination.  In one experiment, discrimination based on defendant status was heightened when participant-jurors were led to believe that the crime at trial was becoming more frequent in their neighborhood.  In another experiment, defendant outgroup discrimination increased when the crime was more threatening because the victim was an ingroup member.  In two other experiments, two subtle forms of threat contributed to discrimination based on defendant status, especially among “prevention-focused” participant-jurors who are chronically pre-occupied with preventing negative outcomes.  When their self-esteem was threatened by a pre-trial task that made their most dislikeable personal qualities salient, participant-jurors engaged in greater discrimination.  The same effect was created by having jurors read a news article that graphically warned about an increased terrorism risk.

        Several experiments focused on whether defendant outgroup discrimination can be ameliorated by having the judge, in opening instructions, caution jurors to avoid prejudice as they contemplate the trial.  The results suggest not.  Discrimination against the outgroup defendant that was evident in a control condition that did not include avoid-prejudice instructions, was equally evident in conditions that included either an explicit instruction to avoid prejudice based on "race, ethnicity, gender, or religious affiliation” because these "these factors are not evidence," or a less explicit instruction to avoid being influenced by "dislikes, opinions, and sympathy”.

        Like judge’s instructions, jury deliberation following the video or transcript trial presentation failed to reduce bias against outgroup defendants in individual jurors’ verdict preferences.  In two experiments, defendant outgroup discrimination occurred when participant-jurors had not yet deliberated.  This bias was sustained on individual post-deliberation verdict preferences among participant-jurors who deliberated, whether or not they had given a pre-deliberation preference.  What deliberation did do was produce a leniency effect.  Both ingroup and outgroup defendants were less likely to be seen as guilty following deliberation.

       The 149 juries were diverse in race and ethnicity.  In most juries, the defendant was an outgroup defendant for the majority of jurors.  The proportion of jurors for whom the defendant was an outgroup member was unrelated to whether the jury returned a guilty verdict.  But the race/ethnicity of the defendant did matter.  Juries were significantly less likely to acquit a Black defendant (20%) than a White (50%) or Hispanic defendant (41%).  

       The project provided scientifically-rigorous evidence of bias based on the defendant’s outgroup-or-ingroup racial/ethnic status in the individual verdict preferences of jury-eligible adults participating in a relatively realistic trial simulation.  Neither judge’s instructions nor deliberation proved to be a helpful remedy for such bias.  These outcomes support and advance social-psychological theory that, perhaps outside of awareness, implicit, conditioned beliefs, emotions, and inferences related to prejudice and social identity become infused in the evaluation of trial information.  Such infusion becomes more pronounced when jurors experience a sense of threat to self or security.

       In addition to intellectual merit as a contributor to knowledge and theory, the project has important broader impacts.  The outcomes are relevant to policy and practice in the legal community.  The project provided professional development opportunities for more than a dozen graduate and undergraduate students, many from under-represented populations.  Nine students received financial support for service as research assistants, ranging from full graduate assistantships and tuition remission, to part-time semester-by-semester employment.  The project also included creation of a videotaped trial that can be an important resource for legal researchers.
